For an acute knee injury causing pain and redness:

Initial self-care steps typically include:
- RICE method (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation)

However, since the evidence provided is limited, I recommend:

- Significant bruising

- You can't walk or put weight on it
- The knee looks deformed
- You develop fever or the area feels hot

user_facing_answer.text:
Hello! PharmaMiku here to help with your knee injury! 🌟 Ouch - bumping your knee can really hurt! Let me share some helpful information to make it feel better~ 💕

What's Happening:
• When you bump your knee, it can cause temporary pain and redness
• This is usually a normal response to minor trauma
• Most minor knee bumps heal well with simple home care

Recommended Care (RICE Method):
• Rest: Take it easy and avoid activities that hurt
• Ice: Apply cold packs for 15-20 minutes at a time
• Compression: Use an elastic bandage if you have one
• Elevation: Try to keep your knee raised when resting

Pain Relief Options:
• Over-the-counter pain medications can help
• You can safely use ibuprofen and paracetamol together if needed
• Always follow the dosing instructions on the package

Watch Out For These Warning Signs:
• Severe swelling or pain that gets worse
• Unable to put weight on your leg
• Knee looks different than usual
• Limited movement in the joint
• Significant bruising
• Fever or unusual warmth around the knee

When to See a Doctor:
• Pain is severe or getting worse
• Can't walk on the affected leg
• Knee appears deformed
• Symptoms don't improve after a few days
• You develop a fever

Remember! ✨
• While I'm happy to provide general guidance, I'm not a real doctor
• If you're worried or your symptoms get worse, please see a healthcare provider
• They can properly examine your knee and provide personalized treatment

Stay safe and take care of that knee! 🌸

Sources for more information:
https://example.com/mock

What's Happening:
• When you bump your knee, it can cause temporary pain and redness
• This is usually a normal response to minor trauma
• Most minor knee bumps heal well with simple home care

Recommended Care (RICE Method):
• Rest: Take it easy and avoid activities that hurt
• Ice: Apply cold packs for 15-20 minutes at a time
• Compression: Use an elastic bandage if you have one
• Elevation: Try to keep your knee raised when resting

Pain Relief Options:
• Over-the-counter pain medications can help
• You can safely use ibuprofen and paracetamol together if needed
• Always follow the dosing instructions on the package

Watch Out For These Warning Signs:
• Severe swelling or pain that gets worse
• Unable to put weight on your leg
• Knee looks different than usual
• Limited movement in the joint
• Significant bruising
• Fever or unusual warmth around the knee

When to See a Doctor:
• Pain is severe or getting worse
• Can't walk on the affected leg
• Knee appears deformed
• Symptoms don't improve after a few days
• You develop a fever

Remember! ✨
• While I'm happy to provide general guidance, I'm not a real doctor
• If you're worried or your symptoms get worse, please see a healthcare provider
• They can properly examine your knee and provide personalized treatment

Stay safe and take care of that knee! 🌸
